image.altText: Jake and Callum Robinson smiling on a beach

props.synopsis: Police in Mexico say they have made another two arrests as they investigate the disappearance of Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson.

title.children: Mexican police make more arrests after Australian surfers go missing

image.altText: Two armed men in camouflage gear, bulletproof vests and helmets look over a valley.

props.synopsis: The region borders the United States, making its popular surf spots driveable locations for visitors from California. But in recent years homicide rates have soared due to ongoing conflict between Mexico's drug cartels.

title.children: What do we know about Baja California, the Mexican state where two Australians have gone missing?

image.altText: Hand holding a magnifying glass over Tasmanian Government letterhead.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's Integrity Commission has warned politicians not to speculate about which MP is under investigation. But an integrity expert says it is a problem of its own making — lashing it as a "useless" organisation.

title.children: 'An unusually useless organisation': Expert blasts Tasmania's 'hopeless' integrity body

image.altText: A photo of Florence wearing a mask.

props.synopsis: Around the world, heated debates about abortion are taking place. But in the Pacific, the topic is so taboo, only a handful of people are willing to talk about it. You’re about to hear from some of them.

title.children: When Florence fell pregnant her one-night stand hated her. She was left to navigate the disturbing world of unwanted children alone

image.altText: Shanika Thomas with mother Jess Tabart.

props.synopsis: A plan for a joyous day at the Burnie public pool for teenager Shanika after a couple of years of poor health quickly turned into a "heartbreaking" ordeal — something her mum says should never have happened.

title.children: 'Heartbreaking': Mum's anguish as daughter waits 16-months for public pool swim

image.altText: A man in a hat gestures as if speaking to a crowd.

props.synopsis: Children of asylum seekers who grew up in Australia are speaking out, fearing they will be forced back to countries they've never known under the government's proposed deportation bill. Immigration lawyers say they were failed by a "cruel" system and it is only about to get worse.

title.children: Hobart businessman Arad arrived to Australia by boat, but a new 'deportation bill' could see his kinsfolk sent back

image.altText: QandAThumb

props.synopsis: Criminologist and former NSW Police detective Vincent Hurley, who went viral lecturing politicians on Q+A, says there are immediate solutions to keep women and children safe.

title.children: 'I don't think it's that hard': The former cop who says he knows how to save more domestic violence victims

image.altText: A portrait of Estelle Rowcliffe on her rural property near Bridgetown in WA's South West.

props.synopsis: While floods in the eastern states have dominated headlines, many creeks in the west have stopped flowing, dams are empty, paddocks are bare and trees are dying. But all bear the fingerprints of a changing climate.

title.children: Estelle’s family has no water to shower or wash clothes. It’s the canary in the coal mine of Australia’s climate change reality

image.altText: An aerial view of suburban Adelaide.

props.synopsis: The National Housing Supply and Affordability Council warns of worsening conditions across the housing system for years to come, unless the government fulfils all of its housing promises.

title.children: New report indicates Australia will miss target of 1.2 million new homes by 2029

image.altText: A green streak of light across a sky

props.synopsis: The Eta Aquariids are one of two meteor showers caused by leftover debris from Halley's comet, and this year could be a cracker — experts predict up to 21 meteors an hour.

title.children: Dark skies promise Eta Aquariid meteor shower will dazzle early birds this weekend

image.altText: Lucy automotive student

props.synopsis: Apprentices will be able to claim up to $10,000 to learn skills such as solar panel installation or electric vehicle repair as part of their trade, as the federal government widens its "new energy" apprentice payment.

title.children: $10,000 payments on offer for apprentices willing to learn clean energy skills as part of their trade

image.altText: a gorup of people marching, a woman holds up a sign that says no more

props.synopsis: A commitment to hire hundreds of domestic violence support workers is yet to be met just weeks from the deadline.

title.children: Deadline fast approaching for domestic violence support workers target

image.altText: Vice Admiral Mark Hammond also directly raised concerns with Chief Admiral Hu Zhongming.

props.synopsis: The chief of navy uses a rare face-to-face meeting with his counterpart in China to warn against continuing unsafe behaviour by the People's Liberation Army-Navy in contested international waters near Australia.

title.children: Australia's navy chief confronts Chinese counterpart over 'unsafe' sonar attack against HMAS Toowoomba

image.altText: Mammogram x-ray image of breasts

props.synopsis: The US is recommending women get regular breast cancer screening from the age of 40. Australia already does this but it's the country's best-kept secret.

title.children: Did you know you may be eligible for free mammograms after 40?

image.altText: Composite image if Nicole Kidman and a calico cat.

props.synopsis: Are you across this week's news headlines? Put yourself to the test.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Bonza cancellations, Nicole Kidman's award and a cat far from home

image.altText: A bronze head of an older woman with short hair, looking serious

props.synopsis: A NSW school has mummified human remains in its library. After years of mystery, a mix of science and art has shed more light on who this person was.

title.children: This Australian school owns a 2,000-year-old human head. Here's what she once looked like

image.altText: A middle-aged man and woman in suits, both with light hair, look serious in a courtyard.

props.synopsis: There are serious questions about ministerial responsibility and administrative competence (or incompetence) that need to be answered, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: O'Neil and Giles dodge the spotlight shining on blunders over ex-detainees

image.altText: A photo showing an Indigenous female senator wearing a white dress with a dark background

props.synopsis: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price was a key player in the Voice No campaign. Six months on from the referendum, the senator says she has no regrets, but her views have come at a cost.

title.children: 'No regrets': Jacinta Nampijinpa Price reflects on being the face of the Voice No campaign

image.altText: Tessa Leggo (1)

props.synopsis: Australia's peak design and planning bodies say they want a say in the 2032 Olympic Games before it's "too late" to make wise decisions.

title.children: Urban planners seek input into Olympic Games design after continuing 'chopping and changing' of plans

image.altText: A composite images of the headshots of Carr and Peters.

props.synopsis: Bob Carr says he intends to sue New Zealand Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters over controversial remarks made on radio this morning after weeks of debate about AUKUS.

title.children: 'He's embarrassed the country': NZ's foreign minister slammed for on air-comments about Bob Carr

image.altText: the exterior of a white apartment building

props.synopsis: The NSW government has announced an inquiry into one of the country's largest strata management firms following revelations on ABC's 730 that it was charging exorbitant insurance fees and taking an untold sum in industry kickbacks.

title.children: NSW government announces inquiry into strata management firm following ABC investigation

image.altText: Anthony Albanese speaks with a woman at a rally against gendered violence

props.synopsis: The unspoken undercurrent of the week is that it's clear there are a lot of men feeling uncomfortable about this conversation. That doesn't make them bad men. It should be uncomfortable.

title.children: 'Be better my dudes': Why lots of men are feeling uncomfortable about the domestic violence conversation

image.altText: a man wearing a beanie and a jacket

props.synopsis: As the country grapples with how to deal with the epidemic of violence against women, perpetrators like Stewart have turned to men's behaviour-change programs for support.

title.children: Stuart hit his partner while drunk. He signed up to a program to try stop it from happening ever again

image.altText: Majib Alibadi, an alleged key figure in Melbourne's tobacco wars.

props.synopsis: An alleged key figure in Melbourne's tobacco wars enjoyed the high life before his arrest, police say, frequenting expensive restaurants and buying designer clothing.

title.children: Alleged key player in Melbourne tobacco wars led life of luxury, say police

image.altText: A woman and man both leaving court separately with their faces blurred.

props.synopsis: A victim of a former husband and wife who had sex with underage employees who worked at their family-owned bakery in regional South Australia in the 1980s has spoken of her "soul-destroying" suffering, saying her abusers "destroyed my adolescence".

title.children: Victim of 'soul-destroying' sexual abuse tells former bakery couple 'you're both monsters'

image.altText: People board plane on tarmac

props.synopsis: A number of strategic issues are blamed for Bonza entering voluntary administration, but some analysts argue it never stood a chance in the first place. Is there still a future where new budget airlines in Australia could thrive?

title.children: Little leg room, crowded aircraft and crammed lockers: Why budget airlines need to do more to survive

image.altText: A man runs the ball during a State of Origin match

props.synopsis: Amid the red-hot battle for a place in the centres for New South Wales, Brisbane star Kotoni Staggs is edging ever close to a Blues recall.

title.children: How the new and improved Kotoni Staggs is pushing for a State of Origin recall

image.altText: A man looks despondent after losing a rugby league match

props.synopsis: The Rabbitohs' start to life without Jason Demetriou and their possible road back to Wayne Bennett is underway, but the loss to Penrith in a soulless stadium might be a preview of further troubles.

title.children: South Sydney faces a long, cold road back from a frozen hell

image.altText: Canterbury Bulldogs general manager Phil Gould talking and gesturing in a screengrab from Channel Nine's 100% Footy program.

props.synopsis: Canterbury football boss Phil Gould cops a $20,000 fine, half of which will be suspended for two years, for making "public comments detrimental to the game" on Channel Nine.

title.children: 'What sort of stupid game is this?': Phil Gould hit with hefty fine by NRL for rant on Channel Nine

image.altText: An older Indigenous woman with shaggy brown hair and glasses wearing a navy blazer

props.synopsis: The Waanyi author's 700-page odyssey Praiseworthy has taken out the prestigious literary award for women and non-binary writers.

title.children: Alexis Wright makes history as the first author to win the $60,000 Stella Prize twice

image.altText: Anonymous people sit inside an Audi car.

props.synopsis: Police are investigating a crash that killed a former police officer and a 24-year-old woman in a Brisbane tunnel on Wednesday afternoon.

title.children: Former police officer killed in Brisbane tunnel crash

image.altText: A man hugs a small alligator to his chest

props.synopsis: Wally's owner Joie Henney says his pet went missing while on vacation and he fears the reptile had been stolen by pranksters, then set free in the wild.

title.children: Wally the emotional support alligator is missing, suspected stolen and set free in the wild

image.altText: People protest outside state parliament.

props.synopsis: For 171 years Adelaide's Crown and Anchor has stood as a site of history and music. Now the battle is on to save the venue from big developers.

title.children: The Superjesus launched themselves at Adelaide's Crown and Anchor. They're joining thousands who want it saved
